title: Avocados, auto parts and ambushes: Inside Mexico’s cargo theft crisis
description: Fraud Watch analyzes Overhaul’s 2025 Q1 Mexico cargo theft report
content: Cargo theft remains a critical threat to logistics networks across Mexico, with the first quarter of 2025 revealing both troubling trends and tactical shifts in criminal behavior. According to Overhaul’s Q1 2025 Cargo Theft Report, an overwhelming 81... [1411 chars]
summary:
Cargo theft in Mexico remains a significant issue in Q1 2025, with 81% of incidents involving violence.
Theft is highly concentrated in Mexico's central and Southeast regions (78%), with 61% in the central region alone.
Two states, Mexico and Puebla, account for 19% each of the national total, being the most dangerous for cargo transport.
Theft has surged in Guanajuato and San Luis Potosí by 3 percentage points compared to Q1 2024.
Most thefts occur from Monday to Friday (82%), with peak activity from Tuesday to Friday (69%).
Dangerous time windows for theft are 6 p.m. to midnight (31%) and 6 a.m. to noon (28%).
Food and beverage shipments are the top target (34%), increasing by 5 percentage points, with avocados as a high-value item.
Other rising categories include auto parts (up 4 points), specifically tires and electrical components, and chemicals such as detergents and plastics (up 1 point).
Home and garden products, especially appliances, have seen a modest increase in theft.

summary:
Prince Andrew's former crisis manager, John Bryan, has admitted to making false claims about Andrew having sex with underage girls.
In 2022, Bryan told the Daily Mail that Andrew was innocent and the victim of Jeffrey Epstein's manipulation, but later said on Piers Morgan Uncensored that he regretted accusing Andrew of lying about having sex with underage girls.
Bryan claimed he was enamored with a female undercover journalist and wanted to please her when he made the false claims.
Bryan also admitted to exaggerating a tabloid scandal in which he was photographed kissing Sarah Ferguson's feet, stating that he was only kissing her toes while Princess Beatrice was sitting next to them.
Andrew has denied allegations of having sex with Virginia Giuffre, who claimed that Epstein trafficked her to have sex with the royal. He settled the lawsuit in 2022 for a substantial sum without admitting liability.
Bryan is known for his association with the royal family, having claimed that he fell in love with Fergie while Andrew was away in the Royal Navy and effectively raised Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie. He has since retracted this statement.

title: Oakland County Sheriff’s Office holds annual Peace Officers Memorial Day Awards Ceremony
description: The Oakland County Sheriff’s Office honored deputies, first responders and local citizens at its annual Peace Officers Memorial Day Awards Ceremony on Wednesday, recognizing those who went above and beyond in moments of crisis.
content:
OAKLAND COUNTY, Mich. – The Oakland County Sheriff’s Office honored deputies, first responders, and local citizens at its annual Peace Officers Memorial Day Awards Ceremony on Wednesday.
The ceremony recognized those who went above and beyond in mome... [1944 chars]
summary:
Oakland County Sheriff’s Office held its annual Peace Officers Memorial Day Awards Ceremony, recognizing acts of heroism in crisis situations.
Command Officer of the Year Award given to Sgt. Joseph Ashley for actions during the Splashpad active-shooter incident in Rochester Hills on June 15, 2024.
Ashley provided lifesaving aid, led SWAT operations, and coordinated a swift response after a gunman wounded 10 people.
Community honoree Allyson Dale raised over $20,000 for six ballistic vests for the sheriff’s K-9 unit, founding the K-9 Defense Fund.
Dale hopes to raise more money to buy as many ballistic vests for K-9 units as possible.
Valor Citation presented to Oakland County Sheriff’s Office Deputy Bradley Reckling’s family.
Deputy Reckling was killed in the line of duty on June 22, 2024, while doing surveillance work on stolen vehicles.
Three suspects fled but were caught; they face multiple charges, including murder of a peace officer.

title: North Shore Remote Day School Set To Shut Down Amid Budget Crunch
description: North Shore Remote Day School Set To Shut Down Amid Budget Crunch - Peabody, MA - The Peabody P.R.E.P. was launched amid the coronavirus health crisis as one of the few district-run virtual schools in the state.
content:
Schools COVID-Era North Shore Remote Day School Set To Shut Down Amid Budget Crunch The Peabody P.R.E.P. was launched amid the coronavirus health crisis as one of the few district-run virtual schools in the state.
Peabody P.R.E.P. enrollment dwindled... [3562 chars]
summary:
The Peabody Personalized Remote Education Program (P.R.E.P.) was launched in Peabody, MA, during the COVID-19 health crisis as one of the few district-run virtual schools in the state.
Enrollment in P.R.E.P. has dwindled, with 109 out of 130 students being in high school grades as of Tuesday night.
The school is set to close at the end of the 2021-2022 school year due to a $5.6 million school budget deficit.
The district plans to reallocate staff members to in-person positions and offer students the option to return to classroom learning or attend other virtual learning academies.
A night remote program will be maintained, with teachers being paid on a stipend basis, allowing day students to attend virtual schooling on a temporary, case-by-case basis.
School Committee member Jarrod Hochman has argued for the virtual school's closure for several years, citing social-emotional impacts of isolation.
Bullying concerns have been a primary reason for students remaining in P.R.E.P., with 800 students choosing to remain remote during the pandemic.
Options will be available for students who do not feel comfortable returning to Peabody Public Schools in person.

title: UNICEF: Western children took multiple hits to their wellbeing from COVID-19
description: The U.N.'s latest audit of the wellbeing of children around the world found that the COVID-19 crisis had severe negative impacts on the classroom performance and mental and physical health of many children.
content: A classroom in Seoul, South Korea, stands empty except for the teacher. A Unicef report out Tuesday blamed enforced home-learning of as long as a year, due to the shuttering of schools during COVID-19, for sharp declines in the academic skills, menta... [3170 chars]
summary:
The United Nations released a report on May 14, 2023, citing the negative impact of COVID-19 on the classroom performance and mental and physical health of children in wealthy countries.
The report compared 2018 and 2022 data from 43 OECD countries, showing that children were underperforming at school, more likely to be overweight/obese, and less happy due to prolonged home-learning during the pandemic.
Academic abilities declined significantly, with students falling 7-12 months behind in reading and math due to 3-12 month shutdowns and remote learning.
Disadvantaged families were hit hardest, with a 4% rise in 15-year-olds who are functionally illiterate and innumerate, amounting to around 8 million students.
Bulgaria, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cyprus, and Mexico were ranked lowest in literacy and numeracy, with two-thirds of 15-year-olds lacking basic skills.
Mental health declined as well, with life satisfaction plunging in 14 of 32 countries, while more children became overweight in 14 of 43 countries.
UNICEF Director Bo Viktor Nylund urged countries to prioritize children's education, health, and wellbeing for long-term prosperity and economic security.
The Netherlands, Denmark, and France were the top three nations for child wellbeing. The United States ranked last, below Norway, Israel, Belgium, and Australia (excluding mental health data).
UNICEF recommended policies supporting skills development, addressing mental health issues, fighting violence, and restricting unhealthy food marketing to children.

General Gregory Guillot warned the U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee that the war in Ukraine could escalate into a direct military conflict with the United States, according to the Pentagon.
Guillot identified several plausible pathways for such escalation, stating that the probability of a direct conflict between the U.S. and one of its key rivals is increasing.
The warning comes more than three years after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, with tensions in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea also posing a constant risk of escalation.
Guillot also mentioned conflicts involving Iran and North Korea, highlighting the Trump administration's challenges in ending the war in Ukraine and combating countries seeking to challenge U.S. military power.
Russian media outlets reported Guillot's comments, which come as anticipation builds over negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, where President Volodymr Zelensky has expressed readiness for direct talks with Putin.

title: Turns out the AC industry is facing what could be its greatest crisis in recent history
description: As of January 1, the federal government mandated a switch to a new refrigerant, R-454B, which is touted as more environmentally friendly. But the transition...
content:
Imagine this: It’s 100 degrees outside. But you’re not worried. You just spent $12,000 on a brand-new air conditioning system that uses the latest government-mandated coolant designed to combat climate change.
There’s just one problem: There’s a seve... [4263 chars]
summary:
On January 1, the federal government mandated a switch to a new refrigerant, R-454B, causing a severe shortage and skyrocketing prices.
The shortage is due to high demand, supply chain problems, limited manufacturers, and confusion about the transition.
The new coolant doesn't work with older AC units, so if a major part breaks, users might need to replace their entire system.
Professionals are expecting a 16-week wait to obtain the new coolant.
Honeywell, a manufacturer of the new coolant, recently added a 42% tariff on it, causing further frustration.
The shortage and tariffs have caused much of the AC industry to remain at a standstill.
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is considering a delay for the conversion, but it would not solve the problem, as companies have already converted their plants and no longer produce the old coolant.
As of now, there is no solution to the shortage and tariffs, making it a significant crisis in the U.S. air conditioning industry.

title: Space debris crisis: the national security threat we're ignoring
description: Space debris crisis: the national security threat we're ignoring
content: Today, Earth’s orbits carry over 100 million debris objects, which have already resulted in nearly 400 debris-generating events, according to NASA. In the last six months alone, space debris has crashed into Poland, near Turks and Caicos, and in Keny... [5282 chars]
summary:
Over 100 million debris objects in Earth's orbits have caused nearly 400 debris-generating events, according to NASA.
In the past six months, space debris has crashed into Poland, near Turks and Caicos, and in Kenya.
The FAA reported 240 flights were disrupted in March due to falling space debris from a failed launch.
GPS generated $1.4 trillion in economic benefits for the U.S. private sector over 33 years.
Disruption to GPS infrastructure could result in nearly $1 billion in daily losses.
On April 30, 2025, the International Space Station maneuvered to avoid debris from a 2005 Long March rocket launch.
The Department of Homeland Security does not acknowledge space infrastructure as a critical infrastructure sector.
OrbitGuardians, a space debris removal company, urges the recognition of space infrastructure as critical and the creation of a Space Infrastructure Security Office.
New funding mechanisms are needed to support space debris removal, including potential tax incentives for U.S. taxpayers.
